awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Multi-Element Illuminication for Mobile Free-Space-Optical Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
As anyone who has used WiFi in urban environments knows, there is interference between multiple competing users and loss of throughput.  Wireless home networks are not just for casual web browsing, but are also being used to stream high-quality video to tablets and other portable devices.  Interference between access points degrades the user experience for these applications.  One method being proposed to address the increased demand for high-capacity local-area wireless networking is Free-space-optical communication (FSOC).  In parallel, solid-state lighting (SSL) devices with multiple light emitting diodes (LEDs) are being deployed and commercialized due to their superior durability and energy efficency. Though stemming from the same core optoelectronics technology, SSL and FSOC have inherent tradeoffs: the illuminated area is larger when the divergence angle of the optoelectronic transmitter is high, whereas the transmission range is longer when it is small. This project envisions multi-element "illuminication" modules that perform joint and adaptive optimization of two conflicting goals: illumination and communication. Such modules and protocols are potentially deployable in many settings such as residential and commercial buildings, airplanes, and other RF-limited environments.

This projects is developing a framework to design, optimize and test illumination-communication technologies considering needs and requirements for both functionalities. To attain mobile illuminication with high spatial reuse and throughput, and uniformly high illuminance; the project designs (i) multi-element illuminication modules which uses spherical structures for spatial reuse and uniform illumination, (ii) adaptive intensity control for energy saving and chromacity control over red-green-blue LEDs, (iii) transceivers with varying field-of-view and divergence angle, (iv) automatic realignment protocols using electronic steering and focusing for mobility, (v) cognitive algorithms for transceiver selection, and (vi) optical wireless localization with high accuracy.

por.por_cntn:
Recent proliferation of wireless technologies and choices available to user applications has triggered a tremendous wireless demand, and the wireless devices are expected to dominate the Internet soon. The availability of wireless resources has caused an ever-increasing variety of applications, such as mobile data, wireless peer-to-peer and sensor networks. Recent reports show that usage of mobile web and Wireless Fidelity (WiFi) by smartphones is increasing sharply, with more than 80% of their data consumption landing on WiFi points. However, radio frequency (RF) based wireless technologies such as WiFi and Long Term Evolution (LTE) have only limited bandwidth which will soon not be enough to respond to the fast-increasing demand. Hence, we urgently need innovations that will enable leveraging of new wireless spectrum bands in order to respond to the exploding mobile wireless traffic demand. This project used the unique advantages of the emerging smart lighting technologies, that utilize Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs), to perform wireless data transfers by piggybacking them on visible light beams. Overarching goal of the project was to investigate and develop multi-element "illuminication" structures that perform joint and adaptive optimization of two goals: illumination and communication.

The scientific merit of the project centered around exploring a visible light communication (VLC) architecture that enables downloading of multiple data streams at the same time. The architecture is hybrid in that it uses VLC to download data to mobile devices and legacy RF such as WiFi to upload data. The key novelty of this approach is the download of multiple data streams from a single access point. The architecture utilizes hemispherical multi-LED bulb designs to enable such simultaneous multi-datastream downloads. Within this context, the project explored optimal configuration of multi-element hemispherical bulbs to provide good lighting and communication coverage across a room. Various parameters such as the room size, the bulb size, as well as the size and intensity of the light beams from each LED were investigated to identify the optimal and near-optimal solutions to the configuration of the VLC network. The project also explored heuristics to assign each LED to users in the room in a fair and efficient manner. Various experiments showed that, by using the multi-element spherical bulb designs, high download link quality and high aggregate throughput can be attained while maintaining an acceptable uniformity of lighting across the room. By utilizing multi-element bulb designs, the project further investigated techniques to localize mobile users at indoor environments where legacy Global Positioning System (GPS) signals may not reach. The project resulted in techniques that combine legacy localization methods (triangulation of omni-directional RF signals) with angle-of-arrival detection using light beams, which showed significant improvement in the accuracy of indoor localization. The project provided advances to multiple scientific fields that include optical wireless systems, mobile networking, wireless communication, and resource optimization.

The illuminication protocols and modules developed in this research have a great potential of implementation and deployment in a wide range of settings, including but not limited to residential and commercial buildings, and military and other high security environments. The protocols further could be included in future communication standards. The envisioned modules could be adopted by architects, designers, civil and electrical engineers in the building industry for the future carbon neutral or net-zero buildings. The broader impacts also included increasing awareness of the community in the potential for using VLC for 5G-and-beyond technologies. The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students in advanced wireless research and resulted in doctoral and masters degrees in national priority technology areas.
